channel.title: We're Hiring iOS Developers
channel.description:
Hey,
Im looking for experienced iOS developers in the UK who would be willing to relocate to yorkshire (its lovely here), It's a fantastic iOS developer position, working closely with other developers and designers to drive forward the exciting projects that we are engaged with on behalf of our clients.
We have some really big clients and work on some great apps, currently a 10 man team looking to expand.
If you are not a iOS developer but know someone who is if they are successfully recruited and within the job for 3 months you will get a £100 cash referral fee. :)
You can inbox me for more information,

item.title: We're Hiring iOS Developers
item.dc:creator: @wyn10 wyn10
item.description:
@wyn10 wrote:

Miss Silabsoft:

i’m too old for this shit! I remember when these lads only worried about making ruler_ cry. Now they are all grown up making job offers and leaving the house

I miss those days…

Read full topic

item.title: We're Hiring iOS Developers
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“tyb97, post:37, topic:546868”][quote author=Vain_ link=topic=665766.msg4452390#msg4452390 date=1412448067]
designing a form is way easier in visual studio - but eclipse’s window builder is extremely easy as well.

though, if you actually know how to draw the frame/work with different layout managers, i would say java is easier.
[/quote]
I highly despise eclipse’s window builder, anything I do with swing is all programatical, but this has it’s problems. I ran into my main issues with the checkers game I was trying to build, as I couldn’t draw images with float precision positioning, and this caused serious issues. However with JavaFX it’s almost necessary to use the scene builder unless you want to sit there all day and type out FXML attributes and such.[/quote]
Could just be a noob and use absolute positioning

Read full topic

item.title: We're Hiring iOS Developers
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:36, topic:546868”]designing a form is way easier in visual studio - but eclipse’s window builder is extremely easy as well.

though, if you actually know how to draw the frame/work with different layout managers, i would say java is easier.[/quote]
I highly despise eclipse’s window builder, anything I do with swing is all programatical, but this has it’s problems. I ran into my main issues with the checkers game I was trying to build, as I couldn’t draw images with float precision positioning, and this caused serious issues. However with JavaFX it’s almost necessary to use the scene builder unless you want to sit there all day and type out FXML attributes and such.

Read full topic

item.title: We're Hiring iOS Developers
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

designing a form is way easier in visual studio - but eclipse’s window builder is extremely easy as well.

though, if you actually know how to draw the frame/work with different layout managers, i would say java is easier.

Read full topic

item.title: We're Hiring iOS Developers
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:34, topic:546868”][quote author=tyb97 link=topic=665766.msg4452290#msg4452290 date=1412381912]
Putting GUI based programs together is just so much easier in a .NET framework than it is in Java, personally at least. Try making a calculator in Swing, then JavaFX, and then C# and tell me which one was better…
[/quote]are you stating this because of visual basic? If so, it’s not a valid statement. As that’s a ide with a gui builder, which Java also has plenty of.

Writing the window, designing, and positioning elements (imo) is way easier in java[/quote]
In my trials, the window builders for Swing have been completely worthless for most practical application, it is easier to just design the JFrame via code, which can get quite troublesome. JavaFX is (from what I’ve heard) an improvement on swing, and has proven to be, although it also has it’s issues, as anything does. Yes, I was referring to visual studio, as that’s all I have experience with, and that has proven to be easier, in my trials of course. Writing applications such as games or GUI’s with lots of functions such as a calculator, has proven to be extremely frustrating.

Read full topic

item.title: We're Hiring iOS Developers
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

[quote=“tyb97, post:33, topic:546868”]Putting GUI based programs together is just so much easier in a .NET framework than it is in Java, personally at least. Try making a calculator in Swing, then JavaFX, and then C# and tell me which one was better…[/quote]are you stating this because of visual basic? If so, it’s not a valid statement. As that’s a ide with a gui builder, which Java also has plenty of.

Writing the window, designing, and positioning elements (imo) is way easier in java

Read full topic

item.title: We're Hiring iOS Developers
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:19, topic:546868”][quote author=Miss Silabsoft link=topic=665766.msg4450906#msg4450906 date=1411262630]
i’m too old for this shit! I remember when these lads only worried about making ruler_ cry. Now they are all grown up making job offers and leaving the house
[/quote]
Haha, don’t say that - I’m only a few years behind you.

And just to be clear, I don’t think this website should become a defacto job board. I was just noting with interest that it was a first. And that makes sense, as a lot of the guys who were around 16 or 17 back in 2006 will be starting to move deeper into their careers, and maybe they will recall peers here that they feel are suitable for offerings where they work.
I’m interviewing for a senior .NET software developer position on Wednesday myself, and that marks a reasonable career progression for me. Despite only having the Java guru award, it’s actually the Microsoft technology stack that I work with professionally. Ironic considering I always made fun of a guy I went to highschool with because of his preference for C#.[/quote]Glad you made the right choice. Once you go C# you never go back.

sorta

Read full topic

item.title: We're Hiring iOS Developers
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Miss Silabsoft:

i’m too old for this shit! I remember when these lads only worried about making ruler_ cry. Now they are all grown up making job offers and leaving the house

Haha, don’t say that - I’m only a few years behind you.

And just to be clear, I don’t think this website should become a defacto job board. I was just noting with interest that it was a first. And that makes sense, as a lot of the guys who were around 16 or 17 back in 2006 will be starting to move deeper into their careers, and maybe they will recall peers here that they feel are suitable for offerings where they work.
I’m interviewing for a senior .NET software developer position on Wednesday myself, and that marks a reasonable career progression for me. Despite only having the Java guru award, it’s actually the Microsoft technology stack that I work with professionally. Ironic considering I always made fun of a guy I went to highschool with because of his preference for C#.

Read full topic

item.title: We're Hiring iOS Developers
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:14, topic:546868”][quote author=tyb97 link=topic=665766.msg4450899#msg4450899 date=1411257772]
Or you could just use LinkedIn, where people who actually have skills are present in large numbers.
[/quote]or we could attempt to use this medium.

rs is dying, moparscape is losing members. all the decent programmers are at an age where a job is needed.

this could potentially spike the growth of the forum in a few months/years.[/quote]I agree, I like the sound of job postings on Mopar as long as they are real and legit and not some prank by a troll.

If I was into programming it could be beneficial for myself and I am sure it could be beneficial for somebody out there as well. When you work in a group of other programmers your style is able to be reviewed and if improvements are offered it can even help you.

Even though I will admit this, for a job posting not a lot of information was given.

Read full topic

item.title: We're Hiring iOS Developers
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:14, topic:546868”][quote author=tyb97 link=topic=665766.msg4450899#msg4450899 date=1411257772]
Or you could just use LinkedIn, where people who actually have skills are present in large numbers.
[/quote]or we could attempt to use this medium.

rs is dying, moparscape is losing members. all the decent programmers are at an age where a job is needed.

this could potentially spike the growth of the forum in a few months/years.[/quote]
Eh, I’ll have to agree with you on this. I am unable to work on any freelancing websites currently as I am just several months shy of being the legal age required. Maybe we could have some sort of middle-man system for people who can’t legally agree to a contract, where a “trusted member” would verify both ends of deals are being completed and no scamming has been attempted, maybe.

the elve age:

I’m sure you’d have better luck if you weren’t asking people to move to Yorkshire, just saying.

True. @OP: Since you’re asking on here you’re probably better off looking for freelance developers who you can pay per-job, and take all the profit from the apps you make.

Read full topic
